questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of gradually worsening shortness of breath. He smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but stopped 8 years ago. His pulse is 72/min, blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg, and respirations are 20/min. Examination shows an increased anteroposterior diameter of the chest. Diminished breath sounds are heard on auscultation of the chest. Chest x-ray shows widened intercostal spaces, a flattened diaphragm, and bilateral basilar hyperlucency. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ANCA-associated vasculitis with antibodies directed against either myeloperoxidase (MPO-ANCA) or proteinase-3 (PR3-ANCA) typically involves small vessels. Because alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) inhibits PR3 activity, current hypotheses suggest that the lack of AAT in patients with A1AD leads to excessive PR3-mediated tissue destruction, and in turn, is more likely to induce an autoimmune response. However, there is currently no evidence to support an increased risk of developing ANCA-positive vasculitis in individuals with A1AD.

B) CORRECT:

About 40% of patients with A1AD develop significant liver damage and cirrhosis, which are common precursors to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), although progression to HCC can also occur in the absence of cirrhosis in these patients. In contrast to the enhanced protease activity leading to excessive breakdown of elastin that causes early-onset emphysema, liver disease is thought to occur due to toxic accumulation of the misfolded alpha-1 antitrypsin protein in hepatic tissue, which significantly increases the risk of liver damage, cirrhosis, and HCC.

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchiolitis obliterans, which occurs as a result of repeated cycles of inflammation and scarring in the small airways, is typically due to inhalation of toxic fumes, graft-versus-host disease in lung transplant patients, or chronic lung infections. However, A1AD is not associated with an increased risk of bronchiolitis obliterans.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with IBD can have associated respiratory complications, including parenchymal disease and airway inflammation, likely through the same underlying inflammatory changes affecting the bowel. While bronchiectasis seems to be the most common pulmonary manifestation of IBD, it would present with a productive cough and only nonspecific bronchial wall thickening on imaging, neither of which are found in this patient. Furthermore, A1AD does not increase the risk of developing IBD.

E) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy is a rare complication in patients with A1AD. When it is seen, it usually occurs alongside liver cirrhosis, which is most likely due to poor clearance of IgA-containing complexes by Kupffer cells in the cirrhotic liver, leading to increased deposition of IgA in the kidneys.

F) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is an interstitial lung disease that is most commonly idiopathic in origin. Occupational hazards (e.g., silicosis), chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., bleomycin), smoking, and infectious diseases (e.g., tuberculosis) significantly increase the risk of progressing to irreversible fibrosis. However, A1AD is not associated with an increased risk of IPF.

G) INCORRECT:

A1AD does not lead to higher rates of lung cancer. Smoking is the single most important risk factor in the development of lung cancer, and this patient is already benefiting from significant risk reduction having quit 8 years ago with only a relatively short 5-pack-year history.
questions.hint: This patient presents with worsening dyspnea and signs of emphysema (barrel chest, diminished breath sounds, lung hyperinflation on x-ray). Given his young age (< 50 years), alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency (A1AD) is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent cough productive of thick, yellow phlegm and increasing shortness of breath. She especially becomes short of breath while playing with her children. She has worked as a farmer for 18 years. She has asthma treated with a salbutamol inhaler. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 12 years. Her pulse is 65/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Scattered wheezing and decreased breath sounds are heard throughout both lung fields. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. The liver is palpable below the right costal margin. Spirometry shows a FEV1:FVC ratio of 66% and an FEV1 of 50% of predicted. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD) is a condition caused by mutations in the SERPINA1 gene, resulting in either decreased AAT levels or reduced AAT activity (severity varies by genotype). AATD leads to uninhibited neutrophil elastase activity in the alveoli and potential polymerization of mutant AAT in hepatocytes. In the liver, this results in the accumulation of mutant AAT, leading to hepatocyte destruction and consequent hepatitis and liver cirrhosis. In the lungs, uninhibited neutrophil elastase activity results in the destruction of the pulmonary parenchyma and consequent panacinar emphysema.

Chest x-ray shows lung emphysema, which can best be visualized on CT. Panacinar emphysema is more commonly seen in nonsmokers with AAT deficiency while centriacinar emphysema is typical of smoking-related emphysema.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with abnormal and irreversible dilation in the bronchial tree (bronchiectasis) present with dyspnea, wheezing, and chronic cough with copious mucopurulent sputum. Spirometry findings in bronchiectasis are consistent with obstructive pulmonary disease. However, a chest x-ray in this condition shows parallel “tram track” lines and thin-walled cysts (in late stages), neither of which are seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view; right lung) and CT (coronal plane; lung window; right lung) of a patient with bronchiectasis

The right lung is diffusely abnormal. Numerous parallel lines (tram track sign; examples indicated by arrows and green lines) representing thickened bronchial walls demarcate lucent air within dilated bronchi. Some thick-walled bronchi are alternatively imaged in cross-section and are visible as circles with lucent centers (examples indicated by red overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchial hyperresponsiveness is part of the underlying pathophysiology of asthma, which manifests with dyspnea and wheezing exacerbated by specific triggers (e.g., exercise) and spirometry findings consistent with obstructive lung disease. Additionally, patients with severe asthma sometimes present with hyperinflation on chest x-ray. However, this patient's palpable liver makes a different underlying cause more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Exposure to environmental allergens (e.g., actinomycete spores) can cause hypersensitivity pneumonitis, which manifests with productive cough and progressive dyspnea. However, a chest x-ray in hypersensitivity pneumonitis shows patchy reticulonodular or diffuse infiltrates (acute form), or ground-glass opacification and emphysema (chronic form). Moreover, this patient may have an enlarged liver, which is not associated with hypersensitivity pneumonitis, and a pulmonary function test in this condition shows a restrictive rather than obstructive pattern.

E) INCORRECT:

Cigarette smoking is the main cause of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which typically manifests with chronic cough and expectoration in patients with a smoking history. COPD also shows a decreased FEV1:FVC ratio on spirometry. However, smoking-induced COPD is unlikely to develop in a patient < 45 years of age with a 6-pack-year smoking history. Furthermore, this patient most likely has an enlarged liver, which suggests a different underlying cause.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (lateral view) of a patient with a history of emphysema

The lungs are hyperinflated with flattening of the hemidiaphragms, widening of the retrosternal space (green overlay), and increased anteroposterior diameter of the thorax (barrel chest; white bracket).

An area of opacification (red overlay) projecting over the spine above the aortic arch corresponds to an abnormality in the left apex on the PA view.
questions.hint: The patient's chest x-ray shows hyperinflation affecting the lower lung zones, a low, flattened diaphragm, wide intercostal spaces, and horizontal ribs indicating lung emphysema. However, she is relatively young to have emphysema, and her physical examination suggests an enlarged liver.

questions.text: A previously healthy 36-year-old man comes to the physician for a yellow discoloration of his skin and dark-colored urine for 2 weeks. He does not drink any alcohol. Physical examination shows jaundice. Abdominal and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. Serum studies show increased levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST). A liver biopsy is performed and a photomicrograph after periodic acid-Schiff-staining is shown. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?

choices.text: Bullous changes of the lung bases on chest CT
Beading of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts on ERCP
Myocardial iron deposition on cardiovascular MRI
Dark corneal ring on slit-lamp examination

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tropheryma whipplei-specific RNA on PCR is diagnostic for Whipple disease, an intestinal disorder caused by infection with the bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. Whipple disease typically manifests as a malabsorptive syndrome with abdominal pain, extraintestinal symptoms (e.g., arthritis, fever, polyserositis), and PAS-positive macrophages on intestinal biopsy. However, signs of hepatic damage and PAS-positive inclusion bodies as seen in this patient would not be expected.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of duodenal tissue (H&E stain)

There are goblet cells (colorless cells; examples indicated by green overlays) within the columnar epithelial cells and immune cells (examples indicated by black arrowheads) within the lamina propria. There are numerous macrophages (single and in loose aggregates) within the lamina propria, causing blunting of the villi.

These findings are characteristic of Whipple disease.

B) CORRECT:

Bullous changes of the lung bases on chest CT scan is a typical finding of emphysema, a sequela of AAT deficiency. AAT deficiency is an autosomal codominant disorder associated with liver damage and panacinar emphysema secondary to the proteolytic destruction of alveolar architecture by the enzyme elastase. Hepatic accumulation of AAT presents as PAS-positive, spherical, inclusion bodies on liver biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Beading of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts on ERCP is a diagnostic feature of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). PSC typically presents in middle-aged men with early signs of cholestasis (e.g., jaundice, pruritus, fatigue) and liver damage as seen in this patient. However, "onion skin" scarring and fibrosis of bile ducts on liver biopsy, rather than PAS-positive inclusion bodies, would be expected. In addition, PSC is usually associated with other autoimmune diseases, especially ulcerative colitis (UC). This patient shows no signs of UC such as bloody stool or abdominal pain.

D) INCORRECT:

Myocardial iron deposition on cardiovascular MRI is found in hemochromatosis. Hemochromatosis is mostly asymptomatic but usually becomes symptomatic between the third and fifth decades of life, with a classic triad of cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, and skin pigmentation. Although hemochromatosis presents with liver damage, the biopsy findings are characterized by positive Prussian blue staining and pronounced iron deposits in hepatocytes rather than PAS-positive inclusion bodies as seen in this patient. In addition, other symptoms such as arthritis, pituitary infiltration, and cardiomyopathy would be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Dark corneal ring on slit-lamp examination (Kayser-Fleischer ring) results from the accumulation of copper in the Descemet membrane of the cornea and is found in ∼ 98% of patients affected by Wilson disease. Although Wilson disease causes hepatic damage, a liver biopsy would show positive copper staining and hepatic copper concentration > 250 μg/g instead of PAS-positive inclusion bodies as seen in this patient. In addition to hepatic and ocular involvement, a broad spectrum of neurologic and psychiatric manifestations would also be expected in Wilson disease.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography of a left eye

A brown ring is visible in the periphery of the cornea (Kayser-Fleischer ring; green overlay).

Kayser-Fleischer rings are typically seen in Wilson disease.
questions.hint: This patient's elevated transaminases and signs of hyperbilirubinemia (jaundice, darkened urine) indicate liver damage. His biopsy findings of PAS-positive, spherical, inclusion bodies in hepatocytes confirm α1-antitrypsin deficiency (AAT deficiency) as the most likely underlying cause.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a 5-year history of worsening shortness of breath and cough comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has never smoked. His pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 130/65 mm Hg, and respirations are 25/min. Examination shows an increased anteroposterior diameter of the chest. Diminished breath sounds and wheezing are heard on auscultation of the chest. An x-ray of the chest shows widened intercostal spaces, a flattened diaphragm, and basilar-predominant bullous changes of the lungs. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Chronic, toxic accumulation of misfolded alpha-1-antitrypsin protein in hepatic tissue causes significant liver damage and cirrhosis, which can progress to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The risk for HCC remains elevated even in the absence of cirrhosis. Liver disease occurs in about 40% of patients with AAT deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Churg-Strauss syndrome is a small-vessel, ANCA-positive vasculitis associated with antibodies directed against either myeloperoxidase (MPO-ANCA) or proteinase-3 (PR3-ANCA). Because alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) inhibits PR3 activity, current hypotheses suggest that the lack of AAT leads to excessive PR3-mediated tissue destruction, and in turn, is more likely to induce an autoimmune response. However, there is currently no evidence to support an increased risk of developing ANCA-positive vasculitis in AAT-deficient individuals.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is an interstitial lung disease that is most commonly idiopathic in origin. Occupational hazards (e.g., silicosis), chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., bleomycin), smoking, and infectious diseases (e.g., tuberculosis) significantly increase the risk of progressing to irreversible fibrosis. However, AAT deficiency is not associated with an increased risk of IPF.

D) INCORRECT:

AAT deficiency does not lead to higher rates of lung cancer. While some case studies have suggested that AAT deficiency could be associated with a higher risk of lung cancer, there is no high-quality evidence of such an association. The baseline risk of lung cancer in this non-smoking patient is thus comparable to the general population.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchiolitis obliterans, which occurs as a result of repeated cycles of inflammation and scarring in the small airways, is typically due to inhalation of toxic fumes, graft-versus-host disease in lung transplant patients, or chronic lung infections. However, AAT deficiency is not associated with an increased risk of bronchiolitis obliterans.
questions.hint: This patient presents with worsening dyspnea and signs of emphysema (barrel chest, diminished breath sounds, lung hyperinflation). The most likely diagnosis is alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency (AAT deficiency), given his young age (< 50 years), lack of smoking history, and x-ray showing evidence of panlobular emphysema (bilateral, basilar hyperlucency) as opposed to centrilobular emphysema (predominantly affects the upper lobes). This early-onset emphysema is caused by excessive breakdown of elastin because protease activity in the lungs cannot be neutralized.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of yellow discoloration of his skin, right upper abdominal pain, and fatigue. Two years ago, he underwent right-sided pleurodesis for recurrent spontaneous pneumothorax. Pulmonary examination shows mild bibasilar crackles and expiratory wheezing. Laboratory studies show an elevation of serum transaminases. Histopathological examination of a tissue specimen obtained on liver biopsy shows PAS-positive globules within periportal hepatocytes. Genetic analysis shows substitution of lysine for glutamic acid at position 342 of a gene located on chromosome 14 that encodes for a protease inhibitor (Pi). This patient most likely has which of the following Pi genotypes?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's medical history and the presence of pulmonary and hepatic involvement suggest α1-antitrypsin deficiency, which is caused by a mutation of the gene that encodes for the protease inhibitor (Pi) α1-antitrypsin. The normal variant of the gene is the “M” type, which can present as either PiMM (both normal alleles) or in combination with one of the mutant forms (i.e., PiMS or PiMZ). Genetic analysis of this patient shows a glutamic acid-to-lysine substitution at position 342, which is characteristic of the “Z” variant. In patients who have inherited both mutant alleles (i.e., PiZZ), pulmonary and hepatic manifestations are most common, and earlier onset of symptoms and more severe disease are more likely to occur, as in this patient.

The severity of disease depends on the specific genotypic expression, which correlates with the amount of α1-antitrypsin protein synthesis: PiMM (normal; 100% expression of normal protein); PiMS < PiSS < PiMZ < PiSZ < PiZZ (decreasing level of α-1 antitrypsin production).

B) INCORRECT:

The PiSS variant of α-1 antitrypsin deficiency occurs as a result of having two mutant alleles for the “S” genotype, which is commonly due to a glutamate-to-valine substitution at position 264 of the α-1 antitrypsin gene. Patients with this genotypic variation often produce enough α-1 antitrypsin to protect the lungs and are typically asymptomatic. This patient's past medical history, site of mutation (i.e., glutamic acid to lysine mutation at position 342), and involvement of both the lungs and the liver suggest a different genotypic variant of the disease.

C) INCORRECT:

The PiMS variant of α-1 antitrypsin deficiency occurs as a result of one normal allele (PiM) and one mutant allele (PiS), which is due to a glutamate-to-valine substitution at position 264 of the α-1 antitrypsin gene. Patients with this subtype range from asymptomatic to mildly symptomatic, most often developing emphysema in response to chronic smoking. Given this patient's severity of symptoms and his genetic analysis, which confirms a lysine for glutamic acid mutation at position 342, he most likely has a different genotypic variation of the disease.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's symptoms and genetic analysis should raise concern for α1-antitrypsin deficiency. Although there are several variants of the disease involving different sites and degrees of mutation, the PiSZ form is associated with a milder form of the disease; it is caused by one mutant allele that occurs due to a glutamate-to-valine substitution at position 264 (PiS) and a glutamic acid to lysine displacement at position 342 (PiZ). Patients with the PiSZ variant are at risk of developing emphysema, especially if they have a history of chronic smoking. This patient has pulmonary and hepatic involvement, however, which suggests a different variation of the disease.

E) INCORRECT:

PiMM is the normal genotypic variant of α-1 antitrypsin gene expression. Individuals who inherit two copies of the “M” alleles produce normal amounts of α-1 antitrypsin, are asymptomatic, and their genetic analysis is unlikely to show any point mutations. This patient's past medical history, liver and lung manifestations, and his genetic analysis suggest a mutation of the Pi gene.

F) INCORRECT:

The PiMZ variant of α-1 antitrypsin deficiency results from one normal allele (PiM) and one mutant allele (PiZ), which is due to a glutamic acid-to-lysine substitution at position 342 of the α-1 antitrypsin gene. Patients with this subtype range from asymptomatic to mildly symptomatic, most often developing emphysema in response to chronic smoking. Although this patient's genetic analysis confirms a glutamic acid-to-lysine mutation at position 342, the severity of his disease and involvement of both the lungs and the liver are inconsistent with this genotypic variation.
questions.hint: This patient's genetic mutation causes a conformational change in the structure of the protease inhibitor α1-antitrypsin (AAT). Hepatic accumulation of AAT manifests as PAS-positive inclusion bodies on liver biopsy and can lead to hepatitis (jaundice, abdominal pain, elevated transaminases).

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 35 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: White, self-identified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I feel like I can't shake this cough.” 
History of Present Illness:


1-year history of a progressively worsening mildly productive cough
reports feeling out of breath when climbing two flights of stairs
also reports malaise, anorexia, and a 4.5-kg (8-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months

no fever

Past Medical History:
unremarkable
Medications:
none
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
pollen, dust mites, animal dander
Family History:


father: died at age 62 years from hepatocellular carcinoma

mother: alive at age 65 years with no chronic conditions

Psychosocial History:

works as a welder in the automotive industry
has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years

does not drink alcohol
occasionally smokes marijuana

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht 
Wt 
BMI


37.2°C(99°F)
80/min
18/min
130/80 mm Hg
96% on RA

182 cm(6 ft)

55 kg(121 lb)
17 kg/m2



Appearance: ill; cachectic 
Skin: dry; no rashes
HEENT: normal conjunctivae and oropharynx
Neck: no jugular venous distention
Pulmonary: barrel chest; diminished lung sounds in all lung fields; expiratory wheezing
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Abdominal: nondistended, nontender;  liver edge palpable at the right costal margin during inspiration
Extremities: nail clubbing; no joint erythema, edema, or warmth; pulses intact

Diagnostic Studies


Blood



 Hemoglobin
14.5 g/dL


 WBC
9000/mm3



 Platelet count
180,000/mm3



Serum



 AST

110 U/L


 ALT

180 U/L


 ALP
85 U/L


 GGT
35 U/L


 Bilirubin, total
1.2 mg/dL


 Direct
0.3 mg/dL



chest x-ray: low and flat diaphragm; widened intercostal spaces; increased basilar radiolucency of both lungs
chest CT: multiple bullae, mostly located at the lung bases



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A sweat chloride test is used to assess for CFTR protein dysfunction in cystic fibrosis (CF), which typically manifests with features of chronic obstructive lung disease including chronic productive cough, expiratory wheezing, digital clubbing, and lung hyperinflation on imaging. CF can also affect the liver and bile ducts, leading to elevated liver enzymes. However, CF usually manifests earlier in life with recurrent pulmonary infections, and other features of CF such as chronic sinusitis, symptoms of bronchiectasis, and pancreatic involvement (e.g., exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, CF-related diabetes) would also be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

A urine antigen test can be used to diagnose histoplasmosis, which can manifest subacutely in immunocompetent hosts with flu-like symptoms including fever, fatigue, and nonproductive cough. Chronic cavitary histoplasmosis can manifest with worsening cough, dyspnea, and weight loss, but unless dissemination occurs, systemic symptoms including lymphadenopathy or hepatomegaly would not be expected. Chest x-ray would reveal diffuse nodal densities, focal infiltrates, or apical cavities. This patient has no risk factors for histoplasmosis (such as immunosuppression or a history of exposure to bird or bat droppings in endemic areas) making this an unlikely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus IgG serology is used to diagnose chronic pulmonary aspergillosis, which can manifest with constitutional symptoms, symptoms of asthma (e.g., shortness of breath, wheezing), productive cough, and recurrent pulmonary infections. However, chronic pulmonary aspergillosis usually affects individuals with severe immunosuppression (e.g., due to HIV) or neutropenia. The combination of pulmonary symptoms, elevated transaminase levels, and a family history of liver disease suggests a different etiology.

D) INCORRECT:

Sputum mycobacterial cultures are used to diagnose tuberculosis (TB), which manifests with constitutional symptoms, shortness of breath, and diminished lung sounds on physical examination. However, imaging would reveal hilar lymphadenopathy, consolidation, Ghon complexes, cavitation, and/or pleural effusion rather than panacinar emphysema. Furthermore, this patient does not have risk factors for TB.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AATD). AATD is caused by a genetic mutation and results in decreased alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) levels or AAT dysfunction, which affects the lungs and the liver. The most appropriate next step would be to perform a serum enzyme assay (e.g., ELISA, nephelometry) to confirm decreased AAT levels in the blood, as well as targeted genotyping.

Management involves limiting exposure to cigarette smoke (active and passive), preventive vaccination (e.g., influenza vaccine, pneumococcus vaccine), symptomatic treatment with bronchodilators, and, in severe AATD or end-stage liver disease, antitrypsin replacement or liver transplantation, respectively.
questions.hint: Progressive cough, dyspnea, elevated liver enzymes, evidence of panacinar emphysema on a chest CT scan (multiple bullae at lung bases), and a family history of liver disease in a young individual should raise concern for a specific inherited genetic disorder.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man with no significant medical history presents with dyspnea on exertion. He reports no cough, orthopnea, lower-extremity edema, or rheumatologic symptoms. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 20 years. He has no family history of lung disease.
He is afebrile, with a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 95% while he is breathing ambient air. His pulmonary examination is notable for reduced air movement bilaterally and a prolonged expiratory phase without wheeze. His cardiac examination reveals no abnormalities. He has no pedal edema or rash.
Spirometry indicates an FEV1 of 69% of predicted, an FVC of 95% of predicted, and an FEV1 /FVC ratio of 0.65. The alpha1-antitrypsin level is 58 mg/dL (reference range, 85–213).
A chest radiograph is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following interventions would have the greatest impact on this patient’s life expectancy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchodilator therapy improves symptoms but not life expectancy in patients with emphysema specifically and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in general.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has mild obstruction on spirometry and a chest radiograph that is consistent with lower-lobe-predominant emphysema (although the distribution of emphysematous change is best established with CT scanning). The most likely diagnosis is alpha1-antitrypsin deficiency accelerated by smoking. This disease rarely manifests before age 40, often at about age 50 in people who have never been smokers. Smoking status is the single best predictor of age of onset and lung-function decline.

Key learning point: In a patient with alpha1-antitrypsin deficiency, smoking cessation will improve life expectancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhaled aerosolized recombinant human deoxyribonuclease is used in patients with cystic fibrosis but is not appropriate for patients with alpha1-antitrypsin deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

The benefits of alpha1-antitrypsin-replacement therapy are controversial, and a survival benefit has not been clearly established.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchodilator therapy improves symptoms but not life expectancy in patients with emphysema specifically and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in general. The same is true of pulmonary rehabilitation.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 25-year-old woman reports frequent infections during the past 3 years, including several sinus infections and two episodes of pneumonia.
A purified protein derivative test, sputum testing for acid-fast bacilli, and HIV serology testing are all negative. A chest radiograph is within normal limits.
Other laboratory testing reveals a normal leukocyte count, and flow cytometry documents normal B-cell and T-cell counts. Immunoglobulin (Ig) G and A levels are low; IgM and IgE levels are normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Common variable immune deficiency (CVID) is a disease of immune dysfunction. Key features include hypogammaglobulinemia, deficient specific antibody responses, and increased risk for autoimmune disorders such as immune thrombocytopenia and autoimmune neutropenia. B-cell and T-cell counts may be normal or low in patients with CVID. Clinical manifestations of CVID include frequent upper and lower respiratory tract infections, as well as recurrent gastrointestinal infections in some cases.

Key learning point: The immunodeficiency disorder that is most likely to be associated with recurrent sinus and respiratory infections in a young adult is common variable immune deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Adult-onset cystic fibrosis or alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency could cause chronic relapsing lung symptoms, but not low immunoglobulin levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic granulomatous disease can cause sinusitis and pneumonia, but it generally manifests in the first two years of life and is also accompanied by abscess formation.

D) INCORRECT:

Complement factor 2 deficiency typically manifests with sepsis rather than recurrent sinus and lung infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Adult-onset cystic fibrosis could cause chronic relapsing lung symptoms, but not low immunoglobulin levels.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of intermittent cough productive of thick, yellow phlegm and increasing shortness of breath. She becomes especially short of breath on exertion. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 12 years. She works as a farmer. Her father died from hepatocellular carcinoma at age 55. Scattered wheezing and decreased breath sounds are heard throughout both lung fields. The liver is palpable below the right costal margin. Spirometry shows a FEV1:FVC ratio of 66% and an FEV1 of 50% of the predicted value. A CT scan of the chest shows destruction of the entire acinus of the lung. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cystic fibrosis (CF) should be considered in patients with features of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, such as dyspnea, cough, and pulmonary obstruction. Panlobular emphysema and hepatomegaly are not characteristic of CF. Moreover, this patient does not have other common features of CF, such as chronic sinusitis, hemoptysis, clubbing, pancreatic insufficiency, and infertility. This patient’s family history makes another diagnosis more likely.

B) CORRECT:

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AAT deficiency) is caused by impaired secretion of the protease inhibitor alpha-1 antitrypsin from cells in the liver, resulting in hepatitis, hepatomegaly, cirrhosis, and early-onset lung emphysema, as seen in this patient. AAT deficiency follows an autosomal codominant inheritance pattern, which explains the hepatocellular carcinoma (likely secondary to AAT deficiency) in the patient's father. While emphysema can be diagnosed on chest x-ray, the panlobular (panacinar) emphysema seen in AAT deficiency is best visualized on a CT scan. Electrophoresis, serum antitrypsin testing, and/or liver biopsy confirm the diagnosis. Whereas panlobular emphysema is associated with AAT deficiency, centiracinar ephysema is typical of smoking-related emphysema.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) typically occurs in patients with a smoking history and manifests with chronic cough and expectoration. COPD shows a decreased FEV1:FVC ratio on spirometry. However, smoking-induced COPD is unlikely to develop in a patient < 45 years of age with a 6-pack-year smoking history. Furthermore, this patient has hepatomegaly and panacinar emphysema on a chest CT scan, which suggests that another diagnosis is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma typically manifests with dyspnea, wheezing, and cough that are exacerbated by exercise and spirometry findings indicating obstructive lung disease. Although hyperinflation may be observed on a CT scan in severe asthma, this patient's hepatomegaly and panacinar emphysema make another diagnosis more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) frequently develops in farmers after weeks to months of repeated antigen exposure and may manifest with productive cough and dyspnea. However, symptoms of emphysema and hepatomegaly are not expected features, and pulmonary function testing in HP typically shows a restrictive pattern. Furthermore, high-resolution chest CT scanning would show ill-defined centrolobular nodules and honeycombing, rather than destruction of the entire acinus of the lung.
questions.hint: This condition is characterized by hepatomegaly and panacinar (panlobular) emphysema on chest CT scan.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with no significant medical history presents with dyspnea on exertion. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 20 years. He has a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 95% while he is breathing ambient air. His pulmonary examination is notable for reduced air movement bilaterally and a prolonged expiratory phase without wheeze. Spirometry indicates an FEV1 of 69% of predicted, an FVC of 95% of predicted, and an FEV1 /FVC ratio of 0.65. The alpha1-antitrypsin level is decreased. A chest x-ray study is obtained (figure). Which one of the following interventions would have the greatest impact on this patient’s life expectancy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchodilator therapy improves symptoms but not life expectancy in patients with emphysema specifically and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in general.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has mild obstruction on spirometry and a chest radiograph that is consistent with lower-lobe-predominant emphysema (although the distribution of emphysematous change is best established with CT scanning). The most likely diagnosis is alpha1-antitrypsin deficiency accelerated by smoking. This disease rarely manifests before age 40, often at about age 50 in people who have never been smokers. Smoking status is the single best predictor of age of onset and lung-function decline.

Key learning point: In a patient with alpha1-antitrypsin deficiency, smoking cessation will improve life expectancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Inhaled aerosolized recombinant human deoxyribonuclease is used in patients with cystic fibrosis but is not appropriate for patients with alpha1-antitrypsin deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

The benefits of alpha1-antitrypsin-replacement therapy are controversial, and a survival benefit has not been clearly established.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchodilator therapy improves symptoms but not life expectancy in patients with emphysema specifically and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in general. The same is true of pulmonary rehabilitation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-year history of gradually worsening shortness of breath. He has a history of smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years, but quit 8 years ago. His pulse is 72/min, blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg, and respirations are 20/min. On examination, he has an increased anteroposterior chest diameter and diminished breath sounds on auscultation. Chest x-ray reveals widened intercostal spaces, a flattened diaphragm, and bilateral basilar hyperlucency. Which one of the following is this patient at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is an interstitial lung disease that is most commonly idiopathic in origin. Occupational hazards (e.g., silicosis), chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., bleomycin), smoking, and infectious diseases (e.g., tuberculosis) significantly increase the risk of progressing to irreversible fibrosis. However, A1AD is not associated with an increased risk of IPF.

B) INCORRECT:

Bronchiolitis obliterans, which occurs as a result of repeated cycles of inflammation and scarring in the small airways, is typically due to inhalation of toxic fumes, graft-versus-host disease in lung transplant patients, or chronic lung infections. However, A1AD is not associated with an increased risk of bronchiolitis obliterans.

C) INCORRECT:

A1AD does not lead to higher rates of lung cancer. Smoking is the single most important risk factor in the development of lung cancer, and this patient is already benefiting from significant risk reduction having quit 8 years ago with only a relatively short 5-pack-year history.

D) CORRECT:

About 40% of patients with A1AD develop significant liver damage and cirrhosis, which are common precursors to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), although progression to HCC can also occur in the absence of cirrhosis in these patients. In contrast to the enhanced protease activity leading to excessive breakdown of elastin that causes early-onset emphysema, liver disease is thought to occur due to toxic accumulation of the misfolded alpha-1 antitrypsin protein in hepatic tissue, which significantly increases the risk of liver damage, cirrhosis, and HCC.

Key learning point: Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency increases the risk of early-onset emphysema and hepatocellular carcinoma due to toxic accumulation of misfolded protein in the liver.

E) INCORRECT:

ANCA-associated vasculitis with antibodies directed against either myeloperoxidase (MPO-ANCA) or proteinase-3 (PR3-ANCA) typically involves small vessels. Because alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) inhibits PR3 activity, current hypotheses suggest that the lack of AAT in patients with A1AD leads to excessive PR3-mediated tissue destruction, and in turn, is more likely to induce an autoimmune response. However, there is currently no evidence to support an increased risk of developing ANCA-positive vasculitis in individuals with A1AD.
questions.hint: This patient presents with worsening dyspnea and signs of emphysema (barrel chest, diminished breath sounds, lung hyperinflation on x-ray). Given his young age (< 50 years), alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency (A1AD) is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of intermittent cough productive of thick, yellow phlegm and increasing shortness of breath, which is worse with exertion. She has a 12-year history of smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily. She works as a farmer. Her father died of hepatocellular carcinoma at age 55. On examination, there is scattered wheezing and decreased breath sounds throughout both lung fields. The liver is palpable below the right costal margin. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 66% and an FEV1 of 50% of predicted. A CT scan of the chest shows destruction of the entire acinus of the lung. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) frequently develops in farmers after weeks to months of repeated antigen exposure and may manifest with productive cough and dyspnea. However, symptoms of emphysema and hepatomegaly are not expected features, and pulmonary function testing in HP typically shows a restrictive pattern. Furthermore, high-resolution chest CT scanning would show ill-defined centrolobular nodules and honeycombing, rather than destruction of the entire acinus of the lung.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) typically occurs in patients with a smoking history and manifests with chronic cough and expectoration. COPD shows a decreased FEV1:FVC ratio on spirometry. However, smoking-induced COPD is unlikely to develop in a patient < 45 years of age with a 6-pack-year smoking history. Furthermore, this patient has hepatomegaly and panacinar emphysema on a chest CT scan, which suggests that another diagnosis is more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Cystic fibrosis (CF) should be considered in patients with features of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, such as dyspnea, cough, and pulmonary obstruction. Panlobular emphysema and hepatomegaly are not characteristic of CF. Moreover, this patient does not have other common features of CF, such as chronic sinusitis, hemoptysis, clubbing, pancreatic insufficiency, and infertility. This patient’s family history makes another diagnosis more likely.

D) CORRECT:

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (AAT deficiency) is caused by impaired secretion of the protease inhibitor alpha-1 antitrypsin from cells in the liver, resulting in hepatitis, hepatomegaly, cirrhosis, and early-onset lung emphysema, as seen in this patient. AAT deficiency follows an autosomal codominant inheritance pattern, which explains the hepatocellular carcinoma (likely secondary to AAT deficiency) in the patient's father. While emphysema can be diagnosed on chest x-ray, the panlobular (panacinar) emphysema seen in AAT deficiency is best visualized on a CT scan. Electrophoresis, serum antitrypsin testing, and/or liver biopsy confirm the diagnosis. Whereas panlobular emphysema is associated with AAT deficiency, centiracinar ephysema is typical of smoking-related emphysema.

Key learning point: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency causes early-onset panacinar emphysema and liver disease, often presenting with both pulmonary and hepatic symptoms in younger adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma typically manifests with dyspnea, wheezing, and cough that are exacerbated by exercise and spirometry findings indicating obstructive lung disease. Although hyperinflation may be observed on a CT scan in severe asthma, this patient's hepatomegaly and panacinar emphysema make another diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: This condition is characterized by hepatomegaly and panacinar (panlobular) emphysema on chest CT scan.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with no significant medical history comes to your clinic with dyspnea on exertion. He has a 20-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes per day. His respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Pulmonary examination reveals reduced air movement bilaterally and a prolonged expiratory phase without wheeze. Spirometry shows an FEV1 of 69% of predicted, FVC of 95% of predicted, and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.65. His alpha1-antitrypsin level is decreased. A chest x-ray is obtained (figure). Which one of the following interventions would have the greatest impact on his life expectancy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has mild obstruction on spirometry and a chest radiograph that is consistent with lower-lobe-predominant emphysema (although the distribution of emphysematous change is best established with CT scanning). The most likely diagnosis is alpha1-antitrypsin deficiency accelerated by smoking. This disease rarely manifests before age 40, often at about age 50 in people who have never been smokers. Smoking status is the single best predictor of age of onset and lung-function decline.

Key learning point: In a patient with alpha1-antitrypsin deficiency, smoking cessation will improve life expectancy.

B) INCORRECT:

The benefits of alpha1-antitrypsin-replacement therapy are controversial, and a survival benefit has not been clearly established.

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchodilator therapy improves symptoms but not life expectancy in patients with emphysema specifically and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in general.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhaled aerosolized recombinant human deoxyribonuclease is used in patients with cystic fibrosis but is not appropriate for patients with alpha1-antitrypsin deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchodilator therapy improves symptoms but not life expectancy in patients with emphysema specifically and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in general. The same is true of pulmonary rehabilitation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency department with progressive shortness of breath over several months. He denies smoking or inhalational exposures. His father died at age 45 from cirrhosis of unclear cause. Vital signs are BP, 118/74; P, 96; R, 22; T, 36.9°C (98.4°F); oxygen saturation, 93% on room air. Chest x-ray shows hyperinflated lungs with diaphragmatic flattening most pronounced at the bases. Laboratory studies show AST 85 Units/L and ALT 90 Units/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate management approach?

choices.text: Admit for liver biopsy and pulmonary function testing
Arrange outpatient hepatology and pulmonology evaluation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Liver biopsy is an invasive procedure and reserved for patients in whom noninvasive testing does not identify a cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Several conditions with symptoms overlapping this patient's presentation (e.g. autoimmune hepatitis, sarcoidosis, asthma) are treated with corticosteroids, and in some severe presentations, empiric therapy without diagnostic confirmation is warranted. This patient is stable and most likely has an underlying condition that is not typically managed with steroids.

C) INCORRECT:

While hepatitis evaluation is used in the work-up of elevated transaminases, this approach misses the multi-system presentation. The combination of early-onset emphysema, liver dysfunction, and family history suggests a genetic condition requiring broader specialist evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

This presentation is not consistent with bacterial pneumonia. The chronic, progressive dyspnea and absence of fever or radiographic infiltrates in combination with elevated transaminases indicate a noninfectious process.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – The combination of early-onset basilar emphysema in a nonsmoker and elevated transaminases with positive family history suggests a alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. Emergency physicians should recognize this pattern, manage any acute respiratory symptoms, and arrange appropriate subspecialty referral for confirmatory testing.
